newsitem.title: UK: T-notes ease in London, wary of upcoming payrolls.
newsitem.headline: T-notes ease in London, wary of upcoming payrolls.

text.p: U.S. Treasuries eased slightly in London on Wednesday and are set for more losses, analysts said.
With little for the market to focus on until Friday's August payrolls data, the session so far had been quiet, they said.
"We've had a short-covering rally off yesterday's lows but I don't trust the market," said a trader at a U.S. bank in London.
"I'm bearish about Treasuries and I think there is more downside to come," she said.
The 30-year benchmark bond was at 96-02 by 0931 GMT, yielding 7.07 percent, compared with 96-05 at the Tokyo and New York closes.
At the short end of the curve Treasuries were also easier.
Two-year T-notes were at 99-20, unchanged from Tokyo and down 1/32 from the New York close. While five-year T-notes were at 99-05, down from 99-06 in Tokyo and 99-07 in New York.
An economist at a British bank in London was also inclined to favour the downside.
"Treasuries had a good day yesterday," he said. "The market will be slightly easier today but there is not a lot going on."
U.S. construction spending for July, due at 1400 GMT, is forecast to fall 0.2 percent compared with a rise of 1.2 percent in June.

"There's not much on the economic front today. We've got construction spending to look forward to later but the non-farm payrolls on Friday will attract most of the attention," the trader said. "A lot of people are on hold until Friday."
August non-farm payrolls are expected to come in at plus 244,000 compared with plus 193,000 in July.
By 0938 GMT, December T-bond futures were at 107-14 in automated trade, up 2/32 from the Chicago settlement.
